urn:contentItem:5V5M-6631-JC3J-X404-00000-00Legislators, some of them bewildered, may do little on tech issues this year2019-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:24ZLexisNexistechnologyLegislators, some of them bewildered, may do little on tech issues this year Tim JohnsonMcClatchy DCWashington

Weighty high-tech issues are likely to flummox Congress again this year, just as they did last year, when lengthy hearings with chief executives of Facebook and Google drew a spotlight to the deep unfamiliarity of some legislators with technology matters.

Rather than tackling issues head on about privacy, data protection, and artificial intelligence, legislators may opt for lesser steps.

Democrats now in control of the House say they will heed growing public clamor about the use -- or misuse -- of personal data by social media platforms and other digital companies. But they acknowledge that little action may emerge from the divided Congress.

Rep. Frank Pallone, a a New Jersey Democrat who chairs the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which covers an array of internet issues, said he will push "policies that protect net neutrality, promote public safety, and provide meaningful privacy and data security protections that are seriously lacking today."

Will that lead to concrete legislation? Other Democrats set the bar low. "I think it's not impossible.... I don't think it's out of the question," said Rep. Pramila Jayapal, a Democrat from Washington state who sits on the House Judiciary Committee.

Some Republicans concur.

"It's going to be around the edges. It's not going to be anything particularly substantive," said Rep. Andy Biggs, an Arizona Republican and member of the conservative Freedom Caucus.

Rep. Paul Tonko questions Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg on data securityRep. Paul Tonko, D-NY, during a House Energy and Commerce Committee hearing, questions Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg about the company collection of user data.

Industry experts voiced concern that inaction on Capitol Hill will allow the muscular lobbying arms of Big Tech companies to mold future regulation, and leave individual states and the European Union to continue with their own regulatory initiatives, bypassing Washington.

"Other countries are defining the rules of the road for us right now," said Andrea L. Limbago, chief social scientist at Virtru, a Washington cybersecurity firm focused on digital privacy.

Only a handful of legislators have a deep understanding of digital technology, and they routinely are called upon to tutor other House members.

"I'm always shocked by the number of colleagues that come to me for advice and perspective," said Rep. Will Hurd, a Texas Republican who studied computer science at Texas A&M before joining the CIA.

Another legislator, Rep. Ted Lieu, a California Democrat, was scornful of a House Judiciary committee hearing Dec. 11 in which Google chief executive Sundar Pichai faced repeated complaints of bias, about how its search engine algorithms function.

"We're not going to be doing those stupid hearings anymore," Lieu said.

During the Google hearing in December, one legislator appealed to Pichai to direct his company to offer more personalized tutorials. Another legislator posed a question to Pichai while holding up an iPhone, a device made by Apple, not Google, suffering ridicule on social media.

How bots are taking over our livesBots make up more than half of all internet traffic and are seamlessly integrated into our everyday lives, here's how they work.

Legislators have not put their best foot forward, Limbago said.

"Shaking an iPhone at a Google exec is sort of the meme we see going everywhere to show the disconnect ... of what the actual state of the tech environment is," Limbago said.

Emerging tech issues that have drawn calls for congressional action include the use of facial recognition technology, activities of large Silicon Valley firms in China, how to secure connected home devices that are part of the Internet of Things, whether to adopt federal standards that pre-empt a patchwork of state laws, and how to protect the personal data of users.

"These are big, gnarly, hard problems that really thoughtful people have to work through, and that's my worry. I don't see that," said Shane Green, the chief executive of the U.S. branch of digi.me, a British company that helps consumers keep control of their own data.

Green said he was taken aback by legislators during hearings with Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg before House and Senate committees last April. He said some legislators failed to understand the "insatiable appetite" of Big Tech to track users for advertising purposes.

"They really just don't understand the basics. In the Facebook hearings, literally a couple people asked how they made money and how they could do all this stuff for free," Green said.

Green worries that legislators might design regulations that hinder companies and stifle innovation, or worse yet, "end up not regulating the companies at all and letting them effectively continue with their bad practices. ... The worst case, candidly, is actually having regulations that are co-opted by the platforms."

Large tech companies like Google have robust operations in the capital.

"They are one of the biggest lobbying powerhouses in Washington," said Tom Galvin, executive director of the Digital Citizens Alliance, a nonprofit focused on internet consumer safety issues.

Congress isn't the only focus of the lobbyists. Other regulatory entities, including attorneys general at the state level, are already molding the tech environment, some with a consumer focus, or in the case of the European Union with a focus on competition and privacy, Galvin said.

Last May, the European Union implemented its General Data Protection Regulation, which enshrines protections for EU citizens of their personal data and restricts its use outside the continent. Potential fines are mammoth - up to four percent of a company's annual global turnover.

But Galvin said such fines are not always a deterrent to Big Tech companies.

"A billion dollar fine to a company like Google is like our dry cleaning. If they can solve this problem with money, they will do it every time," Galvin said.

Secure drop embed

Perhaps more worrisome to Big Tech is the changing public perception among ordinary users, some of whom are voicing privacy concerns to their representatives.

Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi, a Democrat from Illinois who has a mechanical engineering degree, said he hears such constituent concerns routinely.

"They understood they gave up some of their privacy and some of their data but they didn't realize the extent of it. And it feels unfair. So they come to us now, and they're basically saying, 'We need to regulate this industry,'" Krishnamoorthi said.

At least two states have gotten a jump on Washington. Vermont became the first state last May to regulate data broker firms that buy and sell personal consumer information. A California law, which takes effect in January 2020, grants consumers the right to know what data is being collected and what high-tech companies are doing with the data.

On a federal level, no single data privacy law currently exists, although Sen. Brian Schatz, a Democrat from Hawaii, floated a proposal with 14 co-sponsors in mid-December. His is one of three such proposals in the Senate. Sensing a changing public mood, the tech industry has offered support for any federal bill that might override California's privacy law.

Another area with a variety of state laws - and no federal law - is that around disclosure of data breaches. Hurd said he believes there are 47 laws around the country that corporations must comply with when they suffer a hack.

Krishnamoorthi said Capitol Hill shouldn't stand by as states take on such high-tech matters.

"We should not cede our authority to anybody on this particular issue. If some states are moving sooner than others, that's fine. But we need to catch up. ... We need to act," he said.

urn:contentItem:5FT4-STM1-JCW9-X1GK-00000-00Legislature sprints toward finish line2015-04-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:24ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 9ALegislature sprints toward finish lineAndy Sher Chattanooga Times Free Press

NASHVILLE — Tennessee lawmakers today will begin their annual rush toward adjournment, racing through dozens of bills on issues ranging from new restrictions on abortion to school vouchers.

Despite passing a $33.8 budget — the only thing the General Assembly is constitutionally required to do — and resolving major controversies like guns in parks (it passed) and making the Bible the official state book (it didn’t), lawmakers still have plenty of unfinished business.



The House has 110 bills on its calendar today and the Senate has 40. That doesn’t count bills still in committees and measures passed by both chambers with differences that have to be sorted.

Legislative leaders have their fingers crossed, hoping to wrap up this week. A lot of people, businesses, local governments, lobbyists and others are nervously watching to see what lives and what dies.

Here’s a rundown on what’s coming up:

Abortion restrictions: The House is expected to take final action on a previously passed Senate bill that imposes a 48-hour waiting period and mandatory informed consent by a physician for women seeking an abortion. Virtually every one of the 73 Republicans in the GOP-controlled House back the bill, as do some of the 26 Democrats.

School vouchers: The Republican-controlled Senate has already passed this bill, just as it does every session. But it awaits action in the House Finance Subcommittee, where its prospects are unclear. The bill allows low-income parents to use tax dollars to send their children to private or religious schools — Protestant, Catholic, Jewish or Muslim — provided the student’s zoned public school is in the bottom 5 percent for achievement statewide.

The bill starts with 5,000 students, rising to 20,000 within a few years. If not enough parents use the vouchers, they could go to other low-income students attending nonfailing schools if their districts have even just one failing school.

Auto insurance: Decades in the making, this bill finally puts teeth into enforcing the current mandatory insurance law. The bill, which passed the House last week, could affect one of every five vehicle registrations in Tennessee, or about 1.1 million vehicles and their owners who have no insurance.

The state’s 95 county clerks will be required to check a computer to see if vehicle owners have insurance, and reject registrations if they don’t. And they can revoke registrations if insurance is dropped.

Common Core education standards: Action is expected in the House and Senate on a compromise on the state’s Common Core standards for math and English language arts. Republican Gov. Bill Haslam hoped to stall an attack by conservatives on the states-initiated standards aimed at ensuring students know what they should.

The compromise retains Haslam’s current review process. But it officially repeals Common Core standards. And it adds a 10-member commission with four gubernatorial appointees and three each by the House and Senate speakers. The commission would have to OK the new standards before passing them along to the state Board of Education for final approval. Proponents say it will retain high standards. Critics contend it’s simply a rebranding of Common Core.

Municipal deannexation: Rep. Mike Carter, R-Ooltewah, and Sen. Bo Watson, R-Hixson, have a bill letting some city residents initiate referendums to “de-annex” their properties. If a majority of voters in the territory approved, the municipality still could levy taxes to pay for improvements like sewers incurred before the de-annexation.

Watson’s version is ready for floor action. Carter’s bill, a follow-up to his 2014 bill eliminating annexation by ordinance and requiring public votes, is up in the House Finance Committee on Tuesday.

Cities are opposed to de-annexation referendums. “We believe these matters are best handled locally,” said Lacie Stone, a spokeswoman for Chattanooga Mayor Andy Berke.

If the bill passes, Watson thinks some areas forcibly annexed into Chattanooga, such as Hixson, “will look at it.”

“But remember,” he added, “when you get de-annexed your financial responsibilities to whatever improvements that were made don’t go away. I think it’s a reasonable process to remove without undue (burdens) on cities.”

Undocumented students: After passing the Senate 21-12 last week, Sen. Todd Gardenhire’s bill granting in-state college tuition rates to some undocumented students living in Tennessee faces its next big test in the House Finance Subcommittee this week.

As amended, the bill affects would-be students who have been designated “lawfully present” under a 2012 federal program.

“I was surprised at the (Senate vote) margin,” the Chattanooga Republican said. “That’s pretty remarkable. I think this margin gives it a real boost in the House. They were sort of waiting to see what we did.”

App-based rideshare services: Popular online transportation networks like Uber and Lyft are bypassing cities and lobbying legislatures to authorize their operations.

A bill by Watson strips cities’ authority to license and regulate rideshare services and makes them self-regulating. The companies would be required to conduct criminal background checks on drivers.

While traditional taxi services have complained, the battle over the bill has involved Big Tech and Big Insurance. But Uber and Lyft and the major auto insurers compromised, and the bill is on the House and Senate floors this week.

“Uber and Lyft is a whole new concept in legislation and we’re trying to build a model that’s new,” Watson said, who added the bill was “crafted, really, from a national perspective.”

Revenue reform: Senators are expected to take final action on Haslam’s proposed Revenue Modernization Act. Haslam says the bill, passed last week by the House, brings fairness to Tennessee-based companies.

The state could collect its 7 percent sales tax on the online licensing of software by business as well as the purchase of video games.

A major change in state business franchise and excise taxes will benefit companies such as Volks- wagen and McKee Foods, with large workforces and major capital investments in plants and machinery. Changes increase the weight given to sales in the tax formula and decrease the portion for personnel and equipment.

The bargaining and negotiations on the bill were conducted secretly by the Haslam administration and various companies. The bill that originally would have raised some $45 million a year now will bring in about $17 million, according to the state Revenue Department.

Those changes are important, Carter told colleagues last week, citing McKee as an example.

“Let me explain something for all of us in Hamilton County and all of us in Tennessee,” Carter said. “McKee family bakery is a huge employer in the state of Tennessee. Do you realize that without this modernization act, they are paying franchise and excise tax on more than 100 percent of their business, literally because payroll and plant and those things are more weighted?

“So why would they continue to bring more jobs to Tennessee?” he asked. “Why would they continue to build plants in Tennessee when they can go to their other regions throughout the country and not pay that tax.”

The bill is “the first step in a process to correct (that inequity).”

Transportation Equity Fund: A bill makes major changes to the 4.5 cents-per-gallon aviation fuel tax that helps pay for improvements at dozens of Tennessee airports, including Chattanooga’s.

The bill delivers a tax break to Memphis-based FedEx, capping its aviation-fuel tax liability at $10.5 million annually. As a result, the Transportation Equity Fund — now $41 million to $48 million — would shrink by two-thirds.

FedEx pays an average 66 percent to 75 percent of the fund’s annual revenues, which provide an estimated $32 million in annual grants to airports.

Proponents note the state has pumped hundreds of millions into incentives to lure and expand companies like Volks- wagen, and say the break will help keep Fed- Ex from moving refueling operations to other states.

The heads of two Tennessee airport associations — one representing the six major air-carrier airports in Chattanooga, Jackson, Knoxville, Memphis, Nashville and Tri-Cities, and the other representing 65 small general-aviation airports — told a House committee the bill will hurt airports because of the reduced revenue for airport improvements.

Presentation

JOHN SWEENEY, SVP, IR, LEIDOS: Good morning, everyone, and welcome and thank you for coming and joining us for our Leidos investor day. I'm John Sweeney, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for the Company. We are excited to be here with you today to share with you a detailed look into our national security, healthcare and engineering business that, on a combined basis, will generate about $6 billion in revenue this fiscal year.

I look forward to working with all the members of the investment community, and I ask they please contact me if I can be of any assistance to you as we move forward. I would like to ask that you please refer to our cautionary statement outlined in the presentation and also in our SEC filings, as today we will be discussing forward-looking information.

Turning now to our agenda slide for today's meeting, today you are going to hear from members of our executive leadership team, starting with our Chairman and CEO, General John Jumper, who is going to tell you why Leidos is on the path to success. That's going to be followed by an operational overview from Stu Shea, our COO.

Lou Von Thaer and Joe Craver will tell you about their businesses, national security and health and engineering, and provide you a detailed commentary on why their businesses are going to compete and win in the markets going forward. Finally, Mark Sopp, our CFO, is going to take you through our numbers and our outlook for the future.

You will note that we will be fielding questions at various points through the presentation and after each of the sector presentations. We ask that you hold all the financial-related questions until Mark's section, and after his remarks he is happy to answer all the financial questions.

Because we are webcasting today, if you would like to ask a question, we ask that you please raise your hand and one of my colleagues will come over with a microphone. Please state your name and your firm before asking your question. We will be wrapping up at about 12.15 today, at which point we would like to invite you for an informal lunch, where the executive team will be available for further discussion.

With that, I would like to turn it over to John.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Ladies and gentlemen, John Jumper, Leidos CEO.

JOHN JUMPER, CHAIRMAN & CEO, LEIDOS: Good morning, everyone, and welcome. It's a pleasure to have you all here today. I would like to start off by acknowledging the 12th anniversary of 9/11 and to pay our respect to the memories of the loved ones lost that day and to their families and to New York City.

All of us have a personal story about a loved one, a friend or a colleague lost on that day. I myself was in the Pentagon when the airplane hit that building that day. It was my first day of work as the Air Force Chief of Staff.

There's a personal story for all of us including our Company, SAIC, because in so much of our businesses related to national security and because 20% of our workforce are veterans. And we do all remember.

Today is also important because we are preparing for the biggest day in the history of SAIC. And you will see that today we are going to talk about the cherished legacy Company, and I'm going to get the right slide up here. It has inspired to new great companies, Leidos and the new SAIC.

We are joined here today by Tony Moraco and the new SAIC leadership, who you will hear from this afternoon, as we cheer each other on to the next phase in the continued success of the dream started by Dr. Bob Beyster in 1969. But this morning we are here to learn about Leidos, an exciting company, we think an exceptional company tuned to the demands of a changing world, grounded in solutions-oriented technology and design from the ground up to be competitive in any environment. (Plays video)

Today you will meet the leadership team that started with the proud traditions of SAIC and forged this new company we call Leidos, a name extracted from the word Kaleidoscope and intended to capture the vision of many solutions through science and engineering. From our history we will continue to embrace the virtues of close customer intimacy and continue to build on our leadership in applied technology, both proud parts of our legacy, but with a fresh eye on operational and financial efficiencies made possible by the separation.

Our COO, Stu Shea, will tell you about how our fresh look at efficiencies has allowed us to take out more than $200 million in costs and to set us on a journey of continuous improvement that will yield further cost reductions in FY 2015 and beyond. Stu and our CFO, Mark Sopp, will tell you about a shift in our financial priorities toward profit growth with less emphasis on chasing topline revenue.

This reverses both history and habit from the legacy SAIC, when decades of abundant government budgets allowed profits to follow revenue. Our new behavior will put focus on extracting more profit from flatter revenue opportunities on the government side. Leidos will also retain its capability to generate significant cash, and our main message to you today is our increased emphasis on returning cash to our shareholders.

Today you will also hear from our COO and sector presidents, who will describe robust, sustainable businesses well-grounded in markets that serve the vital needs of the nation as well as enduring needs of our families, our communities and the world. They will also tell you about exciting opportunities for growth as the demands for our technology turn into market opportunity. You will see how we are configured to leverage the power of our technology across the enterprise to drive the power of our deep analytic and cyber security into real demands in markets of health, energy and the environment, and to drive ourselves into a $37 billion of addressable markets made available by removing the barriers of organizational conflict of interest.

You will meet a Company that is leveraging 25 years of experience in health engineering, not recent leaps into adjacent markets in response to sequestration. Leidos has the tools ready to take full advantage of commercial growth opportunities in those markets. All of these things have been made possible as a result of a fresh view of ourselves, again made possible by the separation and the ability of both new Companies to focus on their core strengths and capabilities.

Let me take just a moment to briefly describe the Leidos family heritage and how we got here today. I will actually start with myself. I have a unique perspective.

During my 39 years in uniform, including more than 20 years of continuous combat, I was able to see the legacy SAIC from a customer point of view. I saw the dedication of the employees, the unparalleled technical competence delivered in remarkably short cycles, unique skills I didn't see with any other company.

When I retired from active duty I was proud to be able to join the SAIC Board of Directors, and even more proud when selected to be the Chairman and the CEO of a Company that had proven its dedication to the men and women who serve the nation, but not just confined to government work. Commitment and dedication is in the DNA of the Company and resides just as powerfully in the commercial businesses within Leidos.

All this to tell you how proud I am to be here. I tell my team all the time I'm 68 years old. I've got a lot of choices in my life, but I choose to be here doing this today. And the reason I want to be here today is because I know that there is power yet to be unleashed in Leidos, and we intend to demonstrate that power through our performance.

Let's take a look at the Leidos family tree and how it emerged from SAIC. The magnificent employee-owned Company founded by Dr. Bob Beyster in 1969 -- his vision was based on an entrepreneurial model, and he grew that business capitalizing on the courage and success of great people he hired to stand on their own. SAIC flourished as a Company with hundreds of small independent self-supporting operations that nourished a unique intimacy with their customers. The legacy SAIC was 1000 flowers blooming, each garden with its own self-sustaining overhead, its own IT and the freedom to compete, even competing with other entities within SAIC.

The Company culture evolved as an interesting combination of entrepreneurial vigor and the diverse influences of employee ownership. The operating units were fiercely independent, and in many cases resisted attempts to share their talents or products, even if it made sense for the enterprise.

When SAIC went public in 2006, the new leadership increased focus on controlling costs through shared services and IT platforms while rationalizing the business operations from hundreds of small independent operations down to three groups and 15 business units.

My predecessor CEOs, Ken Dahlberg and Walt Havenstein, spearheaded vigorous programs of necessary alignment, consolidation and culture change. And this has been a continuous journey since 2006. Ken and Walt led a Company in an environment that is much different than we are experiencing today. During that time, they were able to install the basic functional needs of the public company -- shared services, the enterprise IT and other necessities of an efficient operation. Without these steps we would not be in a position to take the necessary step of separation we are facing today.

As one member of the team put it, we have stretched the rubber band of changes several times but always seem to snap back to the comfortable old ways and old habits. The point is that this separation allows us to break that rubber band and that the idea to separate is not a flashing revelation prompted by any particular event, but the next step on a journey to fully exploit the potential of a great Company, a step we felt was inevitable but not able to act on up until this point.

While there is much left it to do in this journey of continuous improvement, Leidos now becomes more about being configured to address the future than reconstructing an institution designed to prosper during different times. And this is how we are going to be different.

No longer 1000 flowers blooming but efficiently organized, leveraging resources and technology across the enterprise, able to expand into markets now free from potential conflicts of interest, continuing effective cost reductions from FY 2014 to achieve even more in FY 2015 and build momentum on a journey of continuous improvement. Raise the threshold for effective M&A calibrated against the other tools that are necessary to return value to the shareholders.

The management and the board will be more mindful of building excess cash on the balance sheet with a priority placed on returning that cash to the shareholders. And this is the team that has been engineering these changes and will lead Leidos into the future. Stu Shea becomes the President and Chief Operating Officer of Leidos, coming from his position as COO of SAIC.

Stu brings 30 years of experience from the intelligence world, has been with SAIC since 2005 and was president of our national security business before I asked him to be the COO. Stu is the architect of Project Gemini, which was the project name for our separation transaction, and led that team and redesigned both Companies. His team kept us on schedule with the thousands of decisions required to complete this transaction.

Mark Sopp is our CFO. Mark was the CFO of SAIC and has been with the Company since its IPO in 2006. Mark oversaw the complicated financial extractions and other transactions required to get both Companies to the finish line while completing the consolidation of SAIC headquarters from the West Coast to the East Coast. I can tell you neither Mark nor Stu have slept in a year.

You will also hear today from Joe Craver, [president of our health and engineering] sector, continuing his position from SAIC. Joe is a 25-year veteran. He has served at many levels of both government and commercial businesses and has added scale and value to our commercial segments.

We are also proud to have Lou von Thaer as [president of our national security] sector. Lou has recently come to us from General Dynamics, where he was president of their [advanced information systems] business. Like Stu, Lou is a 30-year veteran of the national security business world with a strong background in the most advanced technologies of the cyber world.

Our Board of Directors is equally distinguished and superbly qualified. It is made up of sitting and former executives representing leadership in defense policy, defense and commercial technology, government and commercial health, energy, environment and engineering as well as the worlds of consulting and finance.

So by the end of the day I hope that you all are as excited as I am about the future of Leidos, a $6 billion applied solutions Company with a proud heritage, a broad and established customer base, a diverse portfolio that serves government and commercial markets and a rich history of growth, all fueled by 25,000 superbly talented employees who know how to win.

And this is why we think you should be interested in Leidos. It's a stable national security revenue base with established 25-year presence in high-growth commercial markets. It is unburdened by organizational conflicts of interest that will expand our addressable market by some $37 billion.

We are on an aggressive journey of continuous improvement, already producing significant rate reductions for FY 2014, on target for FY 2015 and more planned beyond FY 2015. We will enjoy a heightened focus on profitable growth which will be woven throughout our culture.

Mark will later outline our value creation roadmap that employs strict financial discipline and focuses on growing profitability while taking into account our cost of capital and required rates of return. This includes, of course, our continuing leverage of low capital expenditures and our strong ability to generate cash -- all, as I said before, with the shareholder in mind.

If you take one point away today from my remarks, it should be that Leidos' operating philosophy, acquisition strategy, compensation metrics and capital deployment all must pass through the prism that asks a single question, does this create value for our shareholders? This means that the threshold for acquisitions becomes more stringent than it has in the past and is calibrated against other means of returning value to the shareholder.

We believe our immediate focus under the leadership of our board of directors will be to leverage the advantage of our cash generation back to the shareholders with a priority on the right combination of stock buyback and dividend.

With that I am going to pause right now before I turn it over to Stu, and we are going to respect a moment of silence now because it's coming up on 8.46, the time the first airplane hit the buildings.

Thank you. And with that, I would like to introduce my partner, or Chief Operating Officer of Leidos, Stu Shea.

STU SHEA, COO, LEIDOS: Good morning, everyone. It's not lost on me, the importance of this date. I just want to reiterate what John said. 12 years ago today I had a breakfast meeting at 9 AM at Windows on the World to meet my brother that day, who worked in the World Trade Center. And the day before, I had to cancel the trip because one of our customers came out with a request for proposal. So instead I flew over the top of the World Trade Center at 8.30 in the morning, landing at Boston's Logan Airport. And the day is forever emblazoned in my mind.

It's interesting to note, 12 years later, what an important role that SAIC and -- both new SAIC and Leidos had played in the events of the last 12 years.

I am really excited about being here today. One of the interesting things is, as John mentioned, as a principal architect of the Gemini program and the separation of Leidos and SAIC is I have long awaited this day when I could get out and tell folks about what this Company was all about in greater detail. And that day is today. And I think we have a great story.

My goal for the next 30 minutes or so is to lay the groundwork for you to understand why we think Leidos is truly a unique Company and why we believe it will be a sound investment for the future. I plan to cover five topics with you today. First, I want to discuss some global megatrends and what markets that we have targeted and why the creation of Leidos matters.

At the 100,000-foot level, next I want to explain who we are, how our business is structured and what type of work that we will do. And I want to give you some color on the portfolio composition, the team that we have and how we currently operate. Third, I want to share with you a perspective on what makes us distinctive.

Fourth, I will give you a preamble on the value proposition that Mark will cover in greater detail later and how we as a Company will operate. Finally, I will share with you what you should expect from us as a shareholder along the way.

So why does the creation of Leidos matter? Frankly, because the world has many challenges. Whether it's the ongoing threats of weapons of mass distraction, the fear of global pandemics, the fragility of our own precious natural resources, we live each and every day under the looming peril of our own existence.

You throw in on top of that a real threat for us to be able to conduct commerce through the disruption in our daily lives by non-kinetic cyber warfare, there is indeed a convergence of global imperatives that requires immediate and comprehensive attention. And these global imperatives are due in part to the convergence of megatrends across the globe. And these give rise to business opportunities, frankly, in markets that matter.

So whether it's health, engineering or national security, the megatrends across the globe are the same. We live in a world that is transnational where economic, geopolitical and urbanization issues are rapidly eliminating the borders between both countries and continents. We've become a global interconnected market. We are operating in an increasingly complex data environment and we are constantly threatened by cyber attacks because of the dependence on that interconnectivity. There has to be a Company that can bring it all together to take a look at these issues from various angles, to innovate, to build solutions and to ultimately secure our future. We believe that Company is Leidos.

So Leidos is a Company that is solving some of the world's most daunting challenges in national security, health and engineering. You will hear a lot today about our 44-year history as SAIC and the fact that we have created this new Company that is really poised to deliver a capability to secure our way of life and our future. And we do this in markets that matter. These are markets that are of enduring nature, and we do it for our families, our communities and our world.

Now, our national security business, listed here on the left, reaches across all parts of the intelligence community, the Department of Defense, the Department of Homeland Security and all branches of the military. We support the full spectrum of military and intelligence operations, from peacekeeping and humanitarian assistance to direct support from combating terrorism, cybercrime and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

In our health business, listed up here in the top right, we help clinicians and healthcare providers, professionals, find new ways to fight disease and reduce medical cost. We are passionate about helping both our federal and our commercial health customers to prevent, diagnose and treat illnesses by modernizing electronic health records, by turning that data into meaningful information enhancing biomedical research and through improved efficiencies across the healthcare system.

And in our Leidos engineering business, listed here on the bottom right, we are energized about building the facilities, the networks, the infrastructure and the solutions that advance our modern way of life. That includes tackling the growing need for a clean, reliable, secure energy supply and addressing our shared concern for our environment and preserving our natural resources. Throughout today, Lou von Thaer, Joe Craver and Mark Sopp will share with you some of the details on each of those areas.

So who are we? At about $6 billion in size, we start as a formidable competitor in all of our markets. We have mass, scale and focus that allows us to compete favorably.

Leidos, as you see here, is structured into two operating sectors. National security sector is our largest sector, comprising roughly two-thirds of the Company's revenue. Lou von Thaer leads that business for us.

In the national security business we are a leading provider of critical mission support for the intelligence community and have a long history of delivering superior research and development, engineering, data analytics and systems integration solutions to both the military, the DoD and DHS. And a significant portion of that business is cyber security. And we believe that these credentials are truly industry-leading.

While many other companies merely redefine information technology and label it as cyber security, our cyber security is much more sophisticated and of greater scale than our competitors. We execute $700 million annually of high-end cyber business. And we have a full range of solutions to anticipate and protect, detect and defend, respond and recover to the major complex cyber attacks that our nation endures. We are the largest provider of cyber analysts to the National Security Agency and other intelligence agencies and we are at the forefront of cyber protection.

Finally, most of our national security employees have the highest level of security clearances, entrusted only to those who carry the full responsibility for our nation's security.

Our health engineering and -- engineering sector is the remaining one-third of Leidos and has some exciting growth areas. Joe Craver leads that business for us. Here we serve both government and commercial customers across a wide variety of markets.

Our strong positioning in commercial business provides an important offset to a pure play defense contractor. We are not a new entrant to these businesses. In both the health and engineering markets we have been doing this for over 20 years of success. We solve hard problems and deliver sustainable solutions that can support a better quality of life for generations to come.

Today, with almost $800 million annually in our health business, of which about $450 million is commercial, we are now a leading provider of electronic health records optimization and implementation in the US.

And moving to our Leidos engineering business, what if you could solve today's energy, environmental and infrastructure challenges while preparing your organization for success in the future? With $1.1 billion annually in our engineering business, we believe we make what-if possible.

We have more than 5000 professionals dedicated to engineering solutions to improve our clients' performance in energy, generation, efficiency in management, environmental services and critical infrastructure design-and-build projects. Together, the health and engineering businesses account for one-third of Leidos' revenues, and nearly two-thirds of that business is commercial.

So let's look a little bit at revenue composition. So now you have a good sense of who we are in the markets that we are targeting, I would like to provide a little bit more clarity around our revenue base and why we believe it's a quality, stable revenue base with what we called low concentration risk.

The first driver, as John mentioned, is -- the quality revenues is our customers. With 50% of our revenues coming from the intelligence community customers, that portion of the business has greater resiliency against sequestration than a pure play defense contractor. Likewise, with 20% of our revenues coming from our growing commercial business we have an important additional offset. The remaining 30% is a combination of our defense and other federal government business.

Another driver of our stable revenues is our contract diversity. Our top 10 contracts account for less than 15% of our revenues, and no individual contract represents more than 3% of our revenue. We have a balanced mix of fixed price and cost-reimbursable contracts. We have a strong base of standard contracts, yet we still also have a wide variety of single-award and multiple-award IDIQ contracts to bid from.

We operate from a prime position on the majority of our contracts and therefore have greater control over our own destiny. And it keeps us close to our customers. With 60% of our technical staff at customer locations, it also gives us excellent insight into the needs of our customer on a continuing basis.

We have limited program exposure on projects that are funded through overseas contingency operations and this only accounts for about 6% of our current revenues. Finally, many of our contracts are classified. So you won't often see announcements of Leidos contract wins in the open literature. So when we win our next $700 million cyber contract, you won't hear much about it in the newspaper.

We also believe we have the right team. The Leidos team is a balance, well-educated workforce that is capable of solving the most daunting problems our customers can throw at us. We employ people of exceptional creativity, expertise and determination. That team is diverse in its years of experience, from seasoned, experienced Baby Boomer and Gen X professionals in science and engineering to the technology-savvy Gen Y and Gen Z employees. The education of our team has a high concentration in the hard sciences with PhDs, medical doctors and a wide range of subject matter experts.

Finally, one thing that John mentioned that we are very proud of is our veterans -- soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines, from the battlefields of Korea to Vietnam, from Granada to Mogadishu, from Kuwait to Baghdad and from Fallujah to Kandahar, the Leidos veterans have long stood as sentinels over America's peace and freedom. Our vets have contributed to the character and greatness of our Company and our nation. Nearly 20% of our employees are vets and we have a proactive hiring campaign to bring and improve those numbers every single day.

Finally, you can see here on this chart our top operating locations. We generally work shoulder to shoulder with our customers across the globe.

So what makes us distinctive? The first is that we are in these three enduring, rich markets. And it starts by delivering science and technology solutions that reflect high priority, long-term global needs. These three markets share an increasingly important convergence of the physical and digital worlds that they represent, and these markets have significant addressable markets for us.

We believe we have a unique opportunity to horizontally integrate our deep success in mission-critical systems with our rapidly emerging technologies in cyber security, together with our demonstrated solutions in big data analytics to deliver the next generation of information-enabled environments.

And whether it's a focus on mission-critical solutions for national security or evolving value-based healthcare through improved data analytics, or bringing science and technology solutions to the engineering business, the future of Leidos is based upon our ability to leverage the entire base of technical capabilities and innovate across the markets.

So how will we do that? One of the things that makes us distinctive is what we call our three strategic levers to help us create solutions. The first lever is our deep customer domain knowledge. We start with deep scientific technology and subject matter expertise and we bring that to our core markets.

What truly distinguishes Leidos, however, is that we have people who understand firsthand the data, the analytic insight and the relevant operational experience in the field. And we extend that all the way through to thought leadership through our patents, publications and outside professional activities of our employees.

As an example, our employees are often sought out for their expertise and judgment in government and industry advisory boards and task forces. Our health IT people are clinicians and medical doctors who know why a system is used, not just how it's used. And our national security folks are retired military and intelligence officers, people whose lives depended on the solutions that Leidos creates.

The second strategic lever we have is our people, our processes and our tools. The people in Leidos are well-educated but they also have all the recognized credentials and industry certifications. To build complex the solutions that lives depend on requires rigorous standards, formalized methodologies and sophisticated modeling and simulation. And Leidos brings a full complement of these people, processes and tools in each of our targeted markets.

And the final strategic lever we have is our scalable capabilities beginning with the core science to understand new phenomenologies, the applied research and development to create system prototypes or subsystems, or the capability to engineer and build complete solutions either through an agile or full lifecycle development approach. Leidos has the scalability to deliver solutions.

So from concept to creation, we bring the rigors of advanced scientific or physics-based research and the ability to manufacture and deliver mission-critical operational systems. And the unique thing about Leidos is the fact that we have all three of those levers deeply embedded in our culture and we have, from the full lifecycle, from concept to creation in each of the market areas. And that is the unique factor that we have.

So together, these three strategic levers combine to allow us to create solutions for what we believe are the most challenging national security, health and engineering problems. Deep customer knowledge, people, processes and tools and scalable capabilities -- these three levers give us a solid foundation for success. And the scale and diversity or capabilities are the core strengths of Leidos.

But on top of that foundation, what Leidos has is a capability that goes well beyond any other company. And that is the ability to create and pull technology across our three markets.

Our ability to leverage technology is unique. There are many companies with technology searching for a buyer. It's kind of like a hammer looking for a nail. Likewise, there are many customers that are seeking a solution to their most pressing problems, and they endlessly search for those solutions. This is the yin and yang of technology solutions.

In each of our three markets, there is a common core of information-driven capabilities. Each market deals with large, unconstrained complex data volumes. That data needs to be protected. And the knowledge derived from that data are required to support real-time, life-saving decisions.

Let me just take a moment here, another moment of silence and celebrate the 12th anniversary of the second plane hitting the towers. Thank you.

In this situation the yin and yang of technology solutions are highly complementary. An important discriminator for Leidos is that we are leveraging our sophisticated cyber security and big data analytics solutions from the national security sector to provide advanced services for healthcare and energy providers.

Now, the intelligence community has long been an early adopter of these critical capabilities. And we at Leidos have been at the forefront of the development of these solutions. We currently have several pilot programs that are already underway where we are taking advantage of the unique skills that we have developed over 25 years plus of R&D, and building solutions in the intelligence community, and applying them to both health care and energy providers.

We also have some additional investments to leverage technology in some areas of differentiated growth in big data analytics and visualization, cloud, cyber security, automated analysis and detection, geospatial systems and mobile device services.

So, as John introduced the Leidos investment thesis, our focus in Leidos is to provide profitable growth and attractive return on capital. As we emerge, we believe that there is a compelling vision and performance objective. We are in the right markets. We are in markets that matter, those with an enduring societal need. And there are unique linkages between those markets and between our differentiated solutions.

We have balanced financial strategy. We enter the market with almost $750 million of cash on the balance sheet. We have a low capital expenditure model, averaging less than 1% of sales.

We anticipate strong free cash flow generation over the planning horizon and we are committed to returning value to our shareholders. We will do that through a combination of regular dividend, buybacks and special dividends and a conservative M&A approach.

Our operating model is repeatable and efficient. We have a stable contract core with a 25-year-plus history, low concentration risk and strong win rate for new business. We have proven science and technology credentials which allow us to innovate and create new solutions.

And we have aligned the organization, our investments, our compensation and the culture with that technology sharing. And we have taken a disciplined look at portfolio management. As we enter Leidos with a constant focus on shareholder performance, we are looking at the divestiture of nonstrategic or nonperforming businesses.

Finally, we have continuously optimized cost structure. We plan on a program of continuous improvement of our indirect cost burden. After taking out $200 million of operating costs from Leidos this past year, we are challenging ourselves to significant savings over the coming year.

Now, you probably saw in our Q2 earnings call from SAIC last week we had a number of issues that impacted our performance. So one might ask, what are you going to do differently going forward in Leidos to avoid these issues? So I'm going to tell you what we are going to do differently.

As part of the creation of Leidos we got the opportunity to take a fresh start. We looked top to bottom, bottom to top, left and right on what worked, what didn't work at what we could do about it as we created both new SAIC and Leidos. So here's what you can expect from us on Leidos going forward.

First, we are going to stay laser focused on our three core businesses. Within those businesses, we will choose carefully what type of contracts we take on. The thousand flowers blooming model of the past is done. No longer will we chase revenue because of our entrepreneurial spirit. Instead, we will channel that incredible energy of our entrepreneurial spirit to focus on growing just in our core markets, our core solutions and providing better value to our customers.

We are setting new standards, tougher standards, for what is considered to be our core business. And we have put in stricter controls to limit our operating units to grow into totally nonadjacent markets. Second, we will continue to expand our focus on commercial business.

With over 20% of our portfolio, we have a goal of expanding our capabilities through organic growth and selective M&A. And third, we will focus on growth through proactive sharing of technology.

Now, historically our investments have been centered on the value that an investment made to a particular part of the Corporation. Today our R&D investments are focused on enterprise contribution. We have stopped worrying about who gets credit for success and have incentivized the teams for enterprise growth.

Right now Lou and Joe are pursuing unprecedented joint investments by leveraging our sophisticated cyber and big data analytics solutions from the national security sector to provide advance services in both healthcare and energy. And we will strive to double our R&D investment over the next four years to focus on enterprise shareholder value, as we believe that our solutions focus will require it.

Fourth, instead of a topline growth culture we will focus on economic profit improvement. We will start that by only pursuing quality revenues. If revenues don't give us a high degree of confidence in generating net profits, they will not be pursued no matter how much fun the contract is.

We have established our incentive system to focus on an enterprise view of profit performance. We are changing our short and long-term incentives to be aligned and primarily focused on profit growth and capital efficiency.

Both Lou and Joe have already set higher-margin thresholds for bids, and bid decisions in general will have stricter controls and occur much earlier in the capture process. Fifth, we will be much more attentive to performance issues through more rigorous technical readiness reviews prior to the proposal submission. We are now conducting regular contract startup reviews with senior management.

Many of our big programs like the recent NASA Human Health and Performance contract have had steady involvement of the executive team since long before the award. And our complex solution programs such as NSA's Key Management Infrastructure program as well as several of our classified projects have had either John or I personally involved in the execution.

We have also tightened up our materials management processes to ensure limited exposure on inventory obsolescence. And our audit and risk assessment processes are being enhanced to provide a more integrated early warning system. To that end, we have established an enterprise risk assessment and execution role reporting directly to me. And that role will be to integrate program execution and provide more proactive support to issue resolution, rather than a more historical investigative and inspection approach.

The bottom line is we have improved our issue escalation process for better early warning. We are getting out in front of issues.

Sixth, we will be very active in the divestiture of nonstrategic or nonperforming businesses. We are not talking about massive scale here; we are talking about smaller organizations. And in Q2 you saw some evidence of this with the announcements of moving one of our lines of business into [DISCO] in preparation for sale.

We are now more than ever incorporating that thinking in Leidos with a constant focus on shareholder performance. And you can expect to see several other portfolio-shaping efforts in the coming quarters.

Seventh, our use of the capital will be much more focused on immediate return to shareholders. We are a cash machine, but we will not be holding excess cash on the balance sheet. We will continue our regular dividend. We will be much more aggressive in buybacks and possibly special dividends.

And if we do M&A, we will do so with much more rigorous attention to shareholder returns. Any M&A will be an established, proven business that bolsters one or more of our three vertical markets. We will not be acquiring startup companies or high concentration-of-risk companies.

As an example, we will not be buying any more single-product acquisitions prior to adoption. And all M&A must be consistent with our focus on profit and returns with attractive ROIs.

Finally, we will expand our new culture of continuous improvement in operational efficiencies. We will institute new Leidos business ecosystems to hone and refine our operating models, reduce overhead costs and incentivize our team for improvements in our SG&A.

We are not just cutting costs, we are fundamentally reshaping how we do business. And we are optimizing every aspect of our business, and nothing is off the table. After taking out $200 million of operating costs from Leidos this past year, we are challenging ourselves to another $50 million to $100 million over the coming year.

Bottom line, SAIC today is a great Company that is splitting into two great Companies. We believe that we can unleash our full potential with the launch of Leidos. We are focused. We are well-positioned in enduring markets that matter in national security, health and engineering, and a solid thread of cyber security running through it all.

We will look at problems from new angles, create innovative solutions to challenging problems. And we are committed to returning value to our shareholders.

We intend to only repay debt in accordance with the amortization schedule that you saw on the previous slide. And as discussed earlier, we intend to deploy all of our excess cash in excess of minimum operating needs for things that we and our Board of Directors feel will maximize that shareholder value. With that, I'd like to turn it over to Tony Moraco, our SAIC Chief Executive Officer, and then we'll come back for questions. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Ladies and gentlemen, Tony Moraco, CEO. TONY MORACO: All right. He's caught up. Fantastic. Okay, I really just want to highlight the investment thesis that we put forward so we can get to questions. We have been through the stack of what we see as a new SAIC -- our market opportunities going forward, leveraging the enterprise that exists today; the excitement of the organization; a year of design, transformation, and optimization. A lot of core themes that you heard supported by Nazzic and John's remarks on customer relationships. We're focused on this market. Our staff, the leadership team at all levels, support the technical as well as the business requirements going forward. The full lifecycle offerings commit us to a one-stop shop for our customers. We have opportunity to expand our current portfolio with each of those, as we described in our growth strategies. There are significant opportunities of scale. Diversified base, I think, protects on the downside, given what we can do to navigate through the next few years in this cycle -- come out that much stronger on the back end, but in turn, take our fair share of the competitive takeaways that we'll experience going forward by leveraging that value proposition, reducing risk, maximizing ability for the customers to actually truly make strategic decisions and deliver on their own strategic requirements. The transformation of the operation model is really one of the fundamental differences of SAIC in the past as well as a distinction of how we're going to operate as separate from Leidos. Our ability to be competitive, drive costs out. John's comments -- we have line of sight of cost reductions against benchmarks so that we can outperform our peers in top line, and bottom line, and shareholder value. We're focused on developing further our subject matter expertise, make sure that it is present with our customers and that value proposition is clear, and fundamentally deliver on solid financial performance. As John said, predictable performance top line; predictable performance bottom line; stable, predictable cash flows; and subsequent distribution of excess cash to our shareholders. We're excited as a leadership team. It's been a long year, but together we are prepared to operate, hit the ground running. As the video stated, restarted new SAIC with a great track record and huge opportunities for success in the future. So with that, I'll invite my colleagues back up, and we'll take your questions. <Transcript UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Get some mics distributed; just hold on a second. Raise your hand again, please. But I think in the long haul, as you think about services, the services sector in this federal space, there may be further consolidations in that small- to mid-tier activities, in part because of just the staying power. There's another dynamic; there's a fair amount of private equity sitting on top of some properties right now, and so they may be looking to shift that portfolio. JOE NADOL: Okay. JOHN HARTLEY: Well, it hasn't fully been defined, but we think we could comfortably go to a 2.8. JOE NADOL: Why were you less specific than your counterparts? TONY MORACO: Less specific on the capital deployment? Well, I think you've got to look at the run rate. UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: In the presentation this morning there was a lot of talk about some of the benchmarks that they are going to be using for incentive compensation. Thinking in terms of dimensions of the matrix, John touched on the customer groups and the account value -- contract value -- entirely for that set of customers. That's what we would call owning revenue. And through delta at cost point, we will manage top-line revenues in that dimension as owning revenue. On the services side, think in terms of their incentives to increase their installed base. If they deliver more assets, more resources, more offerings to broader customers. That's performing revenue. So from a top-line revenue perspective, they are incentivized; and on the owning and performing revenue, and the accounting systems will accommodate that inside of FY 2015. On the bottom end, we've got two dimensions again. Program fees -- responsibility of the customer group. Top line converts on contract to a fee number. That fee converts to profitability. On the service lines, their principle objective on return is utilization of the staff, the resources. So high utilization. You have 90%-plus utilization of staff on direct work. Minimal use of the bench. That will reduce our operating costs; they'll be incentivized on bottom-line performance measures to drive the value that John talked about in profitability. Fee converts through profit, indirect spend before we get to actual cash and earnings numbers. We don't bid things we don't have visibility to. The other risk on the side is your value-added base. If that were to continue that trend of shrinking, you can't cut costs quickly enough to keep up with it. And so therefore that would provide additional risk. So while we say over the long term this is how we expect to operate, I wouldn't make any short-term judgments out of that or see that in any way as forward guidance, just to be safe. GEORGE PRICE: Are there any assumptions about fee capture embedded in the 7% long-term target? JOHN HARTLEY: Absolutely. GEORGE PRICE: Can you talk about them? urn:contentItem:5XY0-T031-DYJW-X1DV-00000-00Lele Pons, Paul Feig and Spotify's Dawn Ostroff Talk Comedic Potential of Podcasts2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:24ZLexisNexisLele Pons, Paul Feig and Spotify's Dawn Ostroff Talk Comedic Potential of Podcasts

LAS VEGAS - The steady rise in listenership for high-end podcasts is opening up a host of opportunities for creatives in the comedy arena, director-producer Paul Feig and internet star Lele Pons told   CES attendees on Wednesday.

Feig, the multihyphenate behind "Bridesmaids" and other hits, invoked the era of great radio dramas thriving as theater of the mind during a panel session with Spotify chief content officer Dawn Ostroff at Variety's Entertainment Summit at the Consumer Electronics Show.

Pons, known for her comedic internet videos, cut a deal late last year with Spotify to create podcasts for the platform.

"I haven't been this excited since I did my first YouTube video," said Pons, who has 15.6 million subscribers to her namesake YouTube channel.

Podcasts can make it possible for creatives to pursue ideas that would be challenging or expensive to shoot in a visual medium. "I have a sci-fi comedy epic that I want to do but it will be expensive," Feig said. "Maybe I'll do it as a podcast like an old radio drama, and that could lead to it being a movie or TV show."

Feig is already producing what he calls a "true crime comedy podcast" for Spotify dubbed "The Case of the Adirondacks." The boom in the podcast sub-genre of true crime podcasts is ripe for comedic touches. "Once there's a language for something we can have fun as comedy people subverting and changing up all that," Feig said.

Ostroff, who joined Spotify last year after leading Conde Nast's digital efforts for seven years, said she sees big potential for podcasts as IP incubators.

"It's another way to have a pillar that is significant in building a brand," Ostroff said. She added that Spotify is working on efforts to "really elevate the level of advertising business we can do in podcasting.

Feig was asked by Variety's Todd Spangler about the prospect of his beloved 1990s NBC dramedy "Freaks and Geeks" having some form of reunion via podcast. Feig created the series, produced by Judd Apatow, that featured a cast of future all-stars including Seth Rogen, James Franco, Linda Cardellini and Jason Segel.

Feig seemed intrigued by the idea but made no commitment. That didn't stop Ostroff from putting down a marker on the project should it ever come to fruition.

"If you decide to do 'Freaks and Geeks' as a podcast, we'll do it with you," she said.

(Pictured: Paul Feig, Lele Pons and   Dawn Ostroff)

urn:contentItem:5VWN-PBH1-JD3N-51MB-00000-00'Lenders must plug into tech investment'2019-04-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 21'Lenders must plug into tech investment'Joyce Moullakis

Commonwealth Bank executive manager Clive van Horen has warned that banks cannot "stand still" on technology investment, even as the immediate focus intensified on credit supply to business and more regulation after the Hayne royal commission.

He said CBA's view from the board down was that technology investment had to remain a constant, despite the other challenges facing the banks.

"The world is moving really fast, whether it's small tech or big tech - with big tech being the Amazons and Apples and Googles of the world who have enormous resources," said Mr van Horen during the AltFi Australasia conference.

"We stand still at our peril as an organisation and if we are not continuing to focus on customer-led innovation, we won't be around in years to come." Mr van Horen, who runs CBA's business customer solutions arm, said that while partnerships with tech groups and burgeoning fintech companies were a "fraught question" for many banks, in his view they were the "only way" forward.

CBA has partnerships with other banks on the Beem It -instant payments app and cloud accounting provider Xero for data feeds, but ended a referral deal with online small business lender OnDeck.

Mr van Horen said investment in risk management and compliance could be done in tandem following the sector's scrutiny by the royal commission.

He appeared at the royal commission last year and was grilled on CBA's overcharging of business overdraft customers and the bank's delayed response to rectifying the issue. It initially put in place a manual process to prevent customers being overcharged but it didn't work.

Yesterday, Mr van Horen outlined an opportunity for CBA to better use data and digital platforms to make it easier for business to get access to loans.

"The strategies of the four banks are broadly quite similar. All of them, and I speak for ourselves, are wanting to grow commercial and business banking," he said. "We are very committed to keep growing in that space." His comments come against a backdrop of increased concerns over an emerging credit squeeze in business lending as banks adopt tighter interpretations of responsible lending laws.

Mr van Horen said falling house prices across Australia were having an impact on the business-lending sector "because of the wealth effect".

At the conference, fledging lenders acknowledged the challenges of responsible lending laws and ensuring a supply of credit.

Judo Capital joint chief Joseph Healy said: "There is a transition, but I don't blame the regulator.

"The industry has lost sight of a lot of core competencies." Mr Healy did not expect banks to be able to repair the damage to their reputations or fix cultural -issues identified at the royal commission for many years. "We all know trust arrives on the back of a tortoise and leaves on the back of a galloping horse," he said.

Judo expected to receive a full banking licence within a week. Mark Jones, the chief of peer-to-peer lender Society One, said regulators had to tread cautiously as a tougher interpretation of lending standards, to weed out a small proportion of fraudulent loans, would affect all borrowers.

"We are seeing the regulator move to the highest common denominator," Mr Jones said.Society One, whose shareholders include News Corporation, was targeting an ASX listing within 12 to 18 months.

urn:contentItem:5XCK-X461-JDJN-64XC-00000-00Lender Stimulating SMEs Development Through Funding2019-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:24ZLexisNexisLender Stimulating SMEs Development Through FundingBamidele Ogunwusi

Callistus Obetta, Group Executive, Technology and Services, FirstBank (left); Gbenga Shobo, Deputy Managing Director, FirstBank (second left); Victor Asemota, founder, Swifta Systems and Services/keynote speaker (middle); Adesola Adeduntan, Chief Executive Officer, FirstBank (second right), and Abdullahi Ibrahim, Executive Director, Public Sector Group, FirstBank, during the FirstBank FinTech Summit 3.0 recently held in Lagos.

Access to funding has been a major challenge facing Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in developing countries. In Nigeria, FirstBank and other banks have been supporting this segment of the economy to grow, Bamidele Ogunwusi writes.

Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) play a major role in most economies, particularly in developing countries. SMEs account for the majority of businesses worldwide and are important contributors to job creation and global economic development, a report by World Bank Group said.

The report, titled: "Improving SMEs' access to finance and finding innovative solutions to unlock sources of capital", said SMEs represent about 90 per cent of businesses and more than 50 per cent of employment worldwide. Formal SMEs contribute up to 40 per cent of national income (GDP) in emerging economies. These numbers are significantly higher when informal SMEs are included.

"According to our estimates, 600 million jobs will be needed by 2030 to absorb the growing global workforce, which makes SME development a high priority for many governments around the world. In emerging markets, most formal jobs are generated by SMEs, which create seven out of ten jobs. However, access to finance is a key constraint to SME growth, it is the second most cited obstacle facing SMEs to grow their businesses in emerging markets and developing countries", the World Bank said.

It added that SMEs are less likely to be able to obtain bank loans than large firms; instead, they rely on internal funds, or cash from friends and family, to launch and initially run their enterprises.

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) estimates that 65 million firms, or 40 per cent of formal micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in developing countries, have an unmet financing need of $5.2 trillion every year, which is equivalent to 1.4 times the current level of the global MSME lending. East Asia and Pacific accounts for the largest share (46%) of the total global finance gap and is followed by Latin America and the Caribbean (23%) and Europe and Central Asia (15%).

The gap volume varies considerably region to region. Latin America and the Caribbean and the Middle East and North Africa regions, in particular, have the highest proportion of the finance gap compared to potential demand, measured at 87 per cent and 88 per cent, respectively. About half of formal SMEs don't have access to formal credit. The financing gap is even larger when micro and informal enterprises are taken into account.

Bridging SME Finance Gap

A key area of the World Bank Group's work is to improve SMEs' access to finance and find innovative solutions to unlock sources of capital.

Loading...

The report reads: "Our approach is holistic; combining advisory and lending services to clients to increase the contribution that SMEs can make to the economy including underserved segments such as women owned SMEs.

"Advisory and Policy Support for SME finance mainly includes diagnostics, implementation support, global advocacy and knowledge sharing of good practice. For example we provide; financial sector assessments to determine areas of improvement in regulatory and policy aspects enabling increased responsible SME access to finance.

"Implementation support of initiatives such as development of enabling environment, design and set up of credit guarantee schemes and improving credit infrastructure which can lead to greater SME access to finance".

In Nigeria, the Development Finance Project supports the establishment of the Development Bank of Nigeria (DBN), a wholesale development finance institution that will provide long-term financing and partial credit guarantees to eligible financial intermediaries for on-lending to MSMEs.

The project also includes technical assistance to DBN and participating commercial banks in support of downscaling their operations to the underserved MSME segment.

As of May 2019, the Development Bank of Nigeria credit line to PFIs for on-lending to MSMEs has disbursed $243.7 million, reaching nearly 50,000 end-borrowers, of which 70 per cent were women, through seven banks and ten microfinance banks.

FirstBank as Game changer

As for FirstBank, the financial support and dedication to SMEs has been impressive as loans given to the SME segment irrespective of product type is N170.3 billion from 2017 to date.

In serving SMEs, banks face robust competition from big tech companies and FinTechs.

According to EY 2019 Global Fintech Adoption Index, 25% of SMEs worldwide have used services in the past six months provided by FinTechs in all of these four categories: banking and payments, financial management, financing and insurance.

FinTechs and big tech companies have raised the bar for all providers. They have delivered innovative solutions and richer user experiences to SMEs for basic financial services, such as customer payments, foreign exchange hedging and cash flow management.

Helped by open-banking trends that encourage financial providers to use open application programming interfaces, FinTechs have made customer onboarding and credit decisioning for SMEs fast and frictionless.

To retain their dominance, banks need to be at the heart of the SME business, using technology to better understand the needs and context of the business, which in turn, will enable banks to better serve their customers.

Banks have responded to the innovation challenge in three ways: by starting neo-banks focused on serving SMEs, partnering with FinTechs and big techs, and building their own technology in-house.

It is in line with this that First Bank partnered with Microsoft to provide supporting technology solutions at discounted rate to over 40 million Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs).

Gbenga Shobo, Deputy Managing Director of FirstBank, said that the Firstbank-Microsoft SME Partnership was the lender's way of lifting SMEs by encouraging them to embrace technology in their operations.

He said that the target was to reach out to about 40 million SMEs and interested individuals as the bank is connecting SMEs with Microsoft to enable the operators improve their operations digitally

"The SMEs can buy some of the Microsoft solutions at discounted rates, pay in naira as against the dollar, thereby removing the stress of exchange rate which is sometimes a challenge for the SMEs. They now have a portal where they can ask for advice on the products and some extra sales support we can also get Microsoft to give them," he said.

He noted that the SMEs may not have been able to get the Microsoft solutions and products on their own, but for the two being the bank's customers have managed to put them together.

"But because Microsoft is our customer and the SMEs are also our customers, we manage to also put them together. Microsoft will also be happy to sell some of their products, so it is a win-win.

"For me, it is the SME; we are trying to promote here. We will continue to do that, this is just the first one to support our large customers."

"We are paying attention to the technology and the SME segment. The SME segment is a very crucial one for us. It is a bigger part of our customer base. We want to start creating more value for them."

Shobo noted that with the partnership, the bank's customers, especially SMEs, could buy the Microsoft applications at discounted rates, and could pay in naira instead of dollars which sometimes was a challenge for them.

According to him, the bank has a portal where the SMEs can ask for advice on the products; there is also extra sales support which the bank can get Microsoft to give to the SMEs if they cannot get it on their own.

"We feel that SMEs are the major drivers of the economy in Nigeria today, because of the challenges of jobs creation and so most people are setting up businesses," he said.

"The SMEs segment is so important to the livelihood of many Nigerians, and we have seen that SMEs have the ability to grow.

Director, Small and Medium Business Middle East and African Headquarter at Microsoft, Arjan Kotte, said the world is going digital, and that SMEs cannot be left behind.

He said one million new devices will be coming online in 2020 while 60 per cent of computing will be in public cloud in 2025 adding that 25 per cent of workers' time is wasted by information overload.

Kotte said that the partnership between Microsoft and FirstBank was meant to help the SMEs take their operations higher in terms of technology and use of the company's product.

He said the company considered FirstBank's reach and customer base as critical in reaching more SMEs that would need Microsoft solutions.

SMEs Portal

One significant bold step that the bank has taken was the launch of the SME portal, tagged "The FirstBank SME portal", a platform through which SMEs can access the unique propositions that have been designed to equip them with the essential tools needed for the growth of their business.

The SME portal is also designed to help SMEs identify various gaps that hinder their business growth leveraging our innovative Business Diagnostics Tool, with a view to proffering tailored solutions and creating opportunities for business improvement, profitability and sustainability.

Following extensive research by the bank over the years, it has identified these seven strategic pillars to be essential for the sustainability and growth of the SMEs.

These include – access to infrastructure, access to talent, capacity building, policy and regulation, access to resources, access to market as well as access to finance. This has duly informed our strategy and propositions for our SMEs going forward.
